Chapter 6: Examination of the Defiled Dharmas and the Defiled One Next, there is a different school that says:
In the ultimate truth, the natures and non-natures of the elements, sense bases, etc. are understood, because they become existent due to their defilement.
As the Buddha said:
The defiled one is attached to defiled dharmas, thus practicing self-harm, practicing harm to others, and practicing harm to both.
In the same way, up to the deluded one being attached to deluded dharmas, the meaning is also so.
The treatise says:

Here there is not a lack of the principle of defilement, although there is like an illusion, because there is no real essence of defilement, etc., but it is merely composed of the accumulation of practices, worldly speech, not the ultimate truth.
Why is it so?
Are these defiled dharmas prior to the defiled one?
Or are they subsequent?
Or do the defiled one and defiled dharmas arise simultaneously?
None of the three is correct.
Therefore the verse says:
If there is a defiled one prior to the defiled dharmas,
How can there be the arising of a defiled one apart from the defiled dharmas?
The commentary says:
This ultimately refutes the separation. If the defiled dharmas have no substance, the defiled one is also so.
It stops what is done. Without ripening, there is no fruit. The ripening of the fruit can be seen.

If apart from the defiled dharmas there is the establishment of the defiled one, then there should be separate defiled dharmas. This is precisely the defiled one obtaining the defiled dharmas through causes.
If so, how can the defiled dharmas be established because of the existence of the defiled one?
Because the defiled dharmas exist, the defiled one is established. Then the defilement arises. This meaning is clearly manifest.
If it is mature, if there is an object of desire, then defiled dharmas are established. If there is no object of desire, how can there be defilement?
One should stop and refute the fault of establishment.
Here, it is also not the case that there is a defiled one first and then the arising of defiled dharmas.
Therefore, the verse refutes:
How can one who is defiled be said to be defiled again?
The explanation says:
Because the defiled dharmas that are the basis have no essence, like what is already mature.
Next, the verse says:
Whether there is defilement or not, the defiled one is also the same.
The explanation says:
If there is a defiled one first and then defiled dharmas, then everywhere it is like the essence of defiled dharmas. Therefore, the principle of a prior defiled one does not exist.
In order to make this meaning clear, therefore the verse says:
The defiled one first has defilement, apart from the defiled one, defilement is established.
The explanation says:
If defiled dharmas do not have the essence of craving that can be made, then in this case, if one sees something accomplished, this is not reasonable.
There is a different school that says:
Apart from the defiled one, there are separate defiled dharmas. Apart from those defiled dharmas, the defiled one can be established.
The treatise says:
If apart from defiled dharmas, the defiled one can exist, this is not so in this case.
Why is it so?
If first there are defiled dharmas and later there is the defiled one, then apart from the defiled one, there are defiled dharmas.
In this case, defiled dharmas do not exist, and there is no principle by which the object of craving can accomplish defiled dharmas, because the object of craving exists later.
For this reason, if apart from the self-nature of the defiled one, defiled dharmas can exist, then those defiled dharmas are accomplished by the defiled one.
In that case, the object of craving cannot accomplish defiled dharmas, because the object of craving exists later, and what is accomplished cannot be obtained.
If this is so, isn't this a fault?
It is also not the case that first there are defiled dharmas and later the defiled one is accomplished.
Furthermore, the verse says:
If there is defilement and the defiled one, how can they be obtained?
The question says:

If there is the defiled one apart from the dharmas of defilement, since there is the fault of mutual dependence, can the two dharmas of the defiled dharmas and the defiled one be established as arising together in this case?
Therefore, the verse answers:
If it is like this and they are born together, it is also not reasonable.
The two, the defiled dharmas and the defiled one, what use are they?
The explanation says:

It means that the two characteristics of the defiled dharmas and the defiled one are mutually contradictory in terms of their nature of separation. If a dharma has not yet arisen, both are without nature. If a dharma has already arisen, what is to be done is without substance. It is only because of the defiled dharmas that are accomplished due to the objects of desire that there is the defiled one.
But those objects of desire and the defiled dharmas that arise are all also refuted.
The question says:
Can the defiled dharmas and the defiled one be combined as having the same nature?
Or are they combined as having different natures?
Therefore, the verse answers:
The defiled dharmas and the defiled one are not of the same nature and do not combine.
The commentary says:
Why is this?
Because they are not of the same nature and can combine. If there are two dharmas that combine, then they are fully established.
Herein, one should know that this is Devadatta giving rise to defilement, and it is not again the cause of that Devadatta, the defiled one.
If he speaks of combining, this is not reasonable.
Moreover, different natures also cannot combine, so the verse refutes by saying:
If different natures were to combine, how could they be obtained?
The commentary says:
If different dharmas with different natures were to combine, they would then be mutually contradictory and not in the same place.
The principle of the arising of two dharmas can be obtained, but later it will be refuted.
Moreover, a verse says:
If a single nature can combine, then even apart from companions it should combine.
The commentary says:
Here, the meaning of combining is the same substance.
In general, a single nature is the meaning of cause.
If this single nature definitely has conjunction, then as explained above, the meaning of conjunction should be seen, therefore there is no single nature cause that can reasonably be conjoined.
Although there is no conjunction that can be established in a single nature cause, if one stops the meaning of conjunction, one should know there is an error.
Furthermore, a verse says:
If different natures have conjunction, then even apart from companions they should have conjunction.
The explanation says:
Here it is said, for example, like a pot and clothes, those different natures cannot be conjoined.
If one establishes conjunction, it is because there is no cause of conjunction of different natures, as before there is then the error of mutual dependence.
If there is something obtained in the conjunction of different natures, then those that are not different natures should also obtain conjunction, how could this be without error?
Furthermore, a verse says:
If different natures have conjunction, then what is the use of the defiled and the defiler?
The explanation says:
Here it is said that there is combination, but there is no principle of combination.
Why is this?
These two dharmas each already have their own separate natures, so there is no separate dharma that can be the object to be combined.
Here there is also no object to be combined that can be obtained, therefore it is known that different natures have no expression.
If it is thought that different natures can have combination, therefore the verse refutes by saying:
If the defiled and the defiler each have their own nature,
If these two have combination, the previous should also be able to combine.
The commentary says:
But how can those two dharmas be said to be established now?
Because each has its own nature.
If the defiled dharma and the defiler are these two, by what meaning do you distinguish the two dharmas each having their own nature to make them combine?
The word or in the treatise means this is the meaning of combination.
If when discrimination arises there is no empty benefit, those natures have nothing to be established.
If you say they are combined, then in this case there is not the slightest defiled dharma that can be made into a defiled dharma, nor is there a defiled one that can exist.
Moreover, the verse says:
Different characteristics cannot be combined, yet you wish to seek to form a combination;
If the combined characteristics have already been formed, you again wish to form their difference.
The commentary says:
The nature of combination is not established, and that meaning is extremely established.

The combination of a single dharma with a different nature cannot be obtained. The extreme establishment of a different nature does not establish the meaning of combination, and therefore there are not two dharmas of defiled dharmas and a defiled one existing simultaneously.
Moreover, different natures may arise in sequence, and they also mutually separate from each other. For this reason, there is no principle of combination in this case.
Now this observation is according to your intended desire. What kind of different natures can arise in sequence?
Or are they simultaneous?
Now, in order to prove this meaning, the verse refutes by saying:
In this way, the defiled and the defiler are neither combined nor not combined;
All dharmas are also like this, neither combined nor not combined.
The commentary says:
What does this mean?
It means that not only are defiled dharmas and the defiled one neither combined nor not combined, all dharmas are also like this.
In the ultimate truth, there are those defiled dharmas such as craving, because they are conditioned, like the eyes and so forth.
The treatise says:
If it is explained like this, because it is universally established, the analogy is not correct.
Why is it so?
If in the ultimate truth there are eyes and so forth, there should be the characteristics of conditioned things such as arising.
If they do not exist, like the horns of a rabbit, there should also be those characteristics of conditioned things.
Therefore, the characteristics of conditioned things are definitely not established in the ultimate truth. How can arising and so forth, the characteristics of conditioned things, be established?
Here, a question should be asked:
Are the things produced by the dominant influence of those arising and so forth conditioned?
Are they unconditioned?
Both are not correct.
Therefore, the verse answers:
If arising is conditioned, then it should have three characteristics.
The explanation says:
Just like the characteristics of the able, the conditioned characteristics here are not like this. How can there be conditioned characteristics?
Here, the two dharmas spoken of are combined, because the three characteristics are universal.
Here, the three characteristics are also completely refuted, because of the self-characteristics of those dharmas.
Furthermore, the verse says:
If arising is unconditioned, it does not make conditioned characteristics.
The explanation says:
Such an establishment should be refuted and its faults removed.
Why is it so?
Because the essence of the unconditioned also has no nature, just like a ceased dharma.
This is the definite determination, with such faults.
In this way, abiding and impermanence, the other dharmas are also the same, all being like the dharma of arising.
The treatise says:
The characteristics are precisely the principle dharmas, with the nature of grasping and holding.
As explained above, how do birth, etc., have their own functions apart from each other?
As explained above, how do birth, etc., become the functions that can be transformed, either separated or not separated?
Moreover, the verse says:
The three dharmas of birth, etc., separated, have no characteristics or functions.
The commentary says:
How can the conditioned dharmas of birth, etc., be transformed in sequence?

If the essence of a dharma has not yet arisen, then the two dharmas of abiding and ceasing cannot serve as its characteristics of the conditioned, because it has not yet arisen, and so the characteristics cannot express anything.

If the self-essence of a dharma has already ceased forever, then the characteristics cannot exist, and so there are no two dharmas of birth and abiding, because that ceased dharma has no nature of its own.
If it has already arisen, then it has no abiding, and if there is no abiding, then there is no birth or cessation either, and it also has no nature.
If it is said that impermanence follows the abiding dharma, then it cannot serve as a characteristic of the conditioned.
Therefore, a verse from the Hundred Treatise says:ğŸ”½How can abiding have the characteristic of cessation?
How can impermanence have abiding?
If there were a dharma of abiding first, later it would not be appropriate.
If there were permanence and impermanence, abiding and permanence would not exist;
Or if there were permanence first, later it would not be permanent.
Impermanence and abiding are the same, if there were a substance,
Permanence would be false, or abiding would also be false.
The meaning of the verse is like this.
If conditioned dharmas are inseparable, how can a single substance be combined at one time?
Therefore the verse refutes:
In one time, arising, abiding, and ceasing do not combine.
The explanation says:
Because they mutually contradict each other.
Some people say:
There is that same type of causal nature that can arise at one time, or it can be accomplished in sequence.
The treatise says:
How is this again?
Or is it attained within that substance?
Or is there something to be attained apart from the characteristics and the characterized?
If there is something to be attained with substance, there is no real substance that can be attained simultaneously with substance, nor is there a cause that is produced separately.

If there is no substance, then there is also no simultaneous arising. Therefore, in substance, there is no such definite arising, etc., like the self-characteristics of arising. How can they be established in sequence?
Furthermore, a verse says:
The characteristics of arising, abiding, and ceasing, are the characteristics of conditioned phenomena.
If they exist, there is an infinite regress; if they do not exist, they are not conditioned phenomena.
The commentary states:
If arising, etc., can be established as separate arising phenomena, then they must definitely have different phenomena that can be established.
In this way, there is the fault of an infinite regress, because the characteristics of conditioned and unconditioned phenomena are not combined.
Next, the VÄtsÄ«putrÄ«ya masters say:
Although the phenomena of arising, etc., are conditioned, how can they be said to be an infinite regress?
Their school's verse says:
The generation of generation only generates the original generation;
The original generation of generation again generates the generation of generation.

The meaning of this verse is that when dharmas are born, along with the dharma's own essence, there are fifteen dharmas that together constitute the dharma of birth. That is to say, there are the dharmas of birth, abiding, difference, and cessation.
This kind of dharma is without distinction. If distinguished and analyzed, there are fifteen dharmas, namely:
1. Birth;
2. Abiding;
3. Cessation;
4. If it is a pure dharma, then the birth of right liberation;
5. If it is a defiled dharma, then the birth of wrong liberation;
6. If it is a dharma not leading to liberation, then the birth of a dharma not leading to liberation;
7. If it is a dharma leading to liberation, then the birth of a dharma leading to liberation;
8. The birth of birth;
9. The abiding of abiding;
10. The cessation of cessation;ğŸ”½11. The retinue of right liberation;
12. The retinue of wrong liberation;
13. Non-liberation dharmas and their retinue;
14. Liberation dharmas and their retinue.
Excluding the original birth itself, there are fourteen dharmas. If the original birth dharma is included, there are a total of fifteen.

The birth of birth and the original birth, these two dharmas are the beginning. In this case, what is produced by the birth of birth is only the birth of the original birth. There is no other dharma produced by the original birth. It still produces the birth of the birth of birth. In this way, it then produces the other dharmas, etc. This then does not fall into the error of infinite regress.
The treatise says:
What is explained like this is all unreasonable.
Therefore, the verse refutes it, saying:
If it is said that the birth of birth can produce the original birth,
The birth of birth arises from the original birth. How can it produce the original birth?
The explanation says:
The essence is like this, because it has no nature.
The next verse refutes it, saying:
If it is said that the original birth can produce the birth of birth,
How can the original birth give rise to the birth of birth?
The commentary says:
The essence of the self-nature is like this, because it has no nature.
Moreover, there is another statement:
When the birth of birth arises, it can give rise to the original birth, because there is no difference.
The next verse refutes this, saying:
If it is said that when the birth of birth arises, it can give rise to the original birth,
If the birth of birth has not yet arisen, how can it give rise to the original birth?
The commentary says:
If the birth of birth has not yet arisen, when it arises, it has no essence. Without essence, it does not arise. What power does it have to be able to give rise to the original birth?
If it has no power, then it cannot be indicated.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
